did.abstract: This collection contains materials related to the lives of Bill and Andy Spence, including folk and traditional music and materials documenting the Fox Hollow and Old Songs Festivals.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: The collection includes reel-to-reel tapes, LPs, photographs, a scrapbook, ephemera, DVDs, and born digital files.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Born in Iowa, spouses Bill (1940-2019) and Kay "Andy" Spence relocated to Voorheesville, N.Y. in 1965. For decades, the two were involved with folk and traditional music in the Capital Region. Initially involved with the Fox Hollow Festival in the late 1960s, the two founded the nonprofit Old Songs, Inc. in 1977 to present folk and traditional music and dance to the public through concerts and group instruction. The first Old Songs Festival was held in 1981 in Guilderland, N.Y. before moving to the Altamont Fairgrounds the following year. Andy Spence served as director of the festival until 2017.

Andy Spence also served as executive director of Old Songs, Inc. until 2018 when she became executive director emeritus. Bill Spence retired from the University of New York at Albany where he worked as a specialist in television, audio, and graphic design in 1998. The two also formed Andy's Front Hall, a full-service mail-order business for selected folk music recordings, books, instruments, and accessories which they operated for decades.

Bill Spence was a musician for more than 60 years. He played banjo, guitar, and Autoharp but was best known for playing the hammered dulcimer. In 1970 he formed a string band named Fennig's All-Star String Band with musicians living in the Albany area brought together by a folk music organization known as "The Pick'n' and Sing'n' Gather'n.'"
Bill and Andy Spence had one daughter Hannah, a graduate of Oberlin Conservatory of Music, Oberlin, Ohio.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Don Person donated 164 reel-to-reel tapes in October 2020. Andy Spence donated materials in August 2021.
